title: Disney Board Votes to Renew CEO Bob Chapek's Contract; Disney CEO will lead world's largest entertainment company for three more years
text:
Mr. Chapek's renewal was closely watched and speculated-on in Hollywood, especially after a high-profile dust-up earlier this year with Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida. Disney, which employs more than 70,000 in the state, took a public stand against the Parental Rights in Education bill, a piece of legislation that curbed classroom instruction on sexual identity and gender in elementary schools.

Disney initially sought to stay out of the debate over the bill—now a law—but was pressured by employees and activists to oppose it. Mr. DeSantis spent weeks railing against Disney as a "woke corporation" that is out of touch with the values of Florida parents and supported a successful effort to strip Walt Disney World of its self-governing status in Orlando.

In addition, Disney's share price has fallen by nearly 40% this year as Wall Street's enthusiasm for streaming video businesses has cooled. Mr. Chapek has set a lofty goal for Disney+ to gain between 230 million and 260 million subscribers and achieve profitability for the direct-to-consumer streaming business by September 2024. It has markedly increased spending on content, including a push into sports broadcasting rights, to attract more subscribers.

The company's share price is up just over half of a percent in after-hours market trading Tuesday.

Since taking over as CEO in February of 2020, Mr. Chapek has also had to put out fire after fire, ranging from last year's clash over pay with Scarlett Johansson, star of the Marvel Studios "Avengers" and "Black Widow" movies, to seeing the company get swept up in a corruption probe in Anaheim, Calif., home to the Disneyland resort and theme park.

Mr. Chapek has also twice dramatically reorganized Disney's corporate structure and overseen the departure of two high-profile executives after they clashed internally with company leadership. In late April, Geoff Morrell, the company's top communications and corporate affairs executive, resigned after just three months with the company, saying he was "not the right fit" for Disney.

And less than three weeks ago, Mr. Chapek fired Peter Rice, the company's top television executive, who oversaw content production for all of Disney's TV networks and streaming services except ESPN, after Mr. Rice clashed with other top executives over budgets and collaboration. Mr. Chapek replaced him with his top lieutenant, Dana Walden.

Mr. Chapek, age 63, joined Disney's home-entertainment division in 1993 after stints at companies like H.J. Heinz. A native of Hammond, Ind.—a blue-collar manufacturing town near Chicago—Mr. Chapek is soft-spoken and burly, in contrast to his predecessor, Robert Iger, who in 15 years as CEO nurtured a reputation as the mayor of Hollywood: an energetic social butterfly with red carpet-ready good looks and a soft touch with talent.

In contrast to his predecessor, who races yachts competitively and lives in a $19 million home in the tony Brentwood section of Los Angeles, Mr. Chapek lives in the comparatively modest Westlake Village neighborhood and vacations at his longtime beach house in the Florida Keys.

Mr. Chapek rose through Disney ranks on the strength of offbeat, but profitable ideas, like expanding the popular direct-to-video "Air Bud" movie franchise. He ran studio distribution and eventually helmed the Parks and Experiences division, which historically has been Disney's biggest profit center.

As the economy has reopened after the pandemic, Disney's theme parks have re-emerged as a robust moneymaker for the company, recording record operating income and revenue in the first quarter of this year. The division's strength has been bolstered by new technology championed by Mr. Chapek that allows theme park visitors to pay extra to skip lines and better plan the logistics of their visits on their smartphones.

The extension of Mr. Chapek's contract is an endorsement of Mr. Chapek's long-term vision for Disney, which according to multiple current and former executives is to convert Disney from a business-to-business oriented company that distributes its content through middlemen like exhibitors, television networks and other rival streaming services, into one that is more focused on giving customers more choice in how they consume content.

That effort centers around Disney+, where in pursuit of Disney's subscriber target, Mr. Chapek has made what current and former executives describe privately as uncomfortable content decisions, such as this summer's decision to expand into more than a dozen new international markets where Disney movies have been censored, and some of which come with low subscription fees that will be hard to convert into profitability.

Catering to Disney+ subscribers in the pandemic was also the motivation behind Disney's decision to skip theatrical release for three recent Pixar animated features, "Luca," "Soul" and "Turning Red," and instead send them directly to Disney+, said Kareem Daniel, Disney's distribution chief, earlier this year. Creative executives at Pixar felt that the decision was disrespectful because their work wasn't shown in theaters, according to two former Disney executives.

But Mr. Chapek's biggest struggle has been to convince Wall Street over the past eight months that Disney is a company worth investing in. Encouraged by investor enthusiasm for the company during the pandemic, when theme parks were closed but Disney+ was signing up tens of millions of customers a quarter, Mr. Chapek signaled an intense commitment to the streaming service.

Disney+ made its debut in late 2019 with healthy subscriber growth that was sent into overdrive by the pandemic, signing up 95 million subscribers in just five quarters. In 2020, Mr. Chapek convened a team including Mr. Daniel, a top lieutenant, and Chief Financial Officer Christine McCarthy, to come up with an updated subscriber target.

In December 2020, he announced the new goal: Disney+ would sign up between 230 million and 260 million subscribers and achieve profitability by September 2024. The target—nearly quadruple the initial guidance laid out by the company—was viewed as ambitious inside and outside of the company, and it didn't take long for investors to bid Disney shares to a record high of $201.91.

But Wall Street's love affair with the streaming video business didn't live happily ever after.

On April 19, Netflix Inc., Disney's biggest streaming competitor, reported its first quarterly subscriber loss in a decade. Disney shares fell by nearly 30% in two months, despite reporting strong quarterly financial results in May, along with better-than-expected Disney+ subscriber growth of its own.

"After the Netflix miss, it became much harder for people who were taking a bullish view of Disney to feel confident," said Doug Creutz, an analyst with Cowen & Co., especially those who felt that Disney had gone "all-in on streaming," he added.

The reaction was swift, even from some of the investors who were the biggest cheerleaders for the turn to streaming video. Red-letter names on Wall Street, including Will Danoff, manager of Fidelity Investments's $130 billion Contrafund, who had met with the Disney board of directors before Disney+ launched and came away impressed, began to turn their backs on the company. Fidelity has cut its Disney holdings by 45% in the past six months, according to securities filings.

Activist investor Dan Loeb, who took a large stake in Disney through his hedge fund, Third Point LLC, and successfully pushed the company to suspend its $3 billion annual dividend and plow the funds instead into the streaming business, has sold all 4.1 million shares it held over the same period, and Disney's name stopped appearing in Mr. Loeb's quarterly letters to investors.

Mr. Loeb, who meets regularly with Mr. Chapek, began to feel that streaming had become a drag on Disney and worried that it would take years before the business showed the kind of profits that would be rewarded with a higher share price, according to a person familiar with his thinking.

"The streaming business is now valued like a liability on the stock, rather than an asset," this person said. "I don't think that anyone in the market really thinks that they're going to hit that subscriptions target. The general consensus on the buy side is that the target may have been too aggressive, and most people don't understand why the company sticks with it."

The Sequoia Fund Inc., a $5 billion mutual fund with about 46% of its assets in tech and media stocks, sold its entire 2.8 million-share position in Disney over the past six months. In an April letter to investors, the fund said it used the proceeds from the sale to increase its position in Netflix.
